thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: Trademark tastes of Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Trademark tastes of Albuquerque, N.M.
persons: Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Kurt Oelsner
Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Carlos Contreras
text:
In Albuquerque, many cultures — Native American, Spanish, Mexican and Anglo influences — meld in a complex stew, all seasoned with a whopping helping of chilis. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Start your Albuquerque, N.M. visit at the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center for an introduction to the culture and history of the area's original "settlers," the indigenous people of New Mexico's 19 pueblos. Don't miss the Pueblo Harvest Cafe at the Cultural Center which features Native Fusion cuisine that pairs indigenous ingredients with cooking techniques and ingredients from around the world — a great place to begin or end your Cultural Center tour. Nick Pecastaing, Pueblo Harvest Cafe Fullscreen Atole, or blue corn porridge, is a traditional Pueblo and Native American dish. Breakfast Atole is served warm and topped with golden raisins, prunes, cranberries, nuts, brown sugar and milk on the side. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Like a Pueblo version of shrimp and grits, Chackewe con Huevos includes atole, spicy carne adovada (chili-braised pork) and eggs. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Party on The Patio at Pueblo Harvest features local bands and pizza fresh from a traditional earthen oven called an horno. Pueblo Harvest Cafe Fullscreen View the Sandia mountains from the Pueblo Harvest Cafe patio. Nick Pecastaing, Pueblo Harvest Cafe Fullscreen Pueblo Harvest's most popular dish is the Tewa Taco where homemade fry bread stands in for the taco. Nick Pecastaing, Pueblo Harvest Cafe Fullscreen Executive chef Michael Geise was named Chef of the Year by the New Mexico Restaurant Association. He and his team are bridging cultures and strive to train a new generation of Native American chefs. Caitlin Cano, Indian Pueblo Cultural Center Fullscreen New Mexico Rack of Lamb is served in ancho chili, pinon (pine nut) and Dijon mustard crust with mint chutney. Ancho chile and pinion are indigenous ingredients that blend perfectly with the more traditional American flavors of mint and mustard. Pueblo Harvest Cafe Fullscreen Acoma Pueblo's Cultural Center and "Sky City," on a giant mesa about 45 minutes from Albuquerque, makes a terrific side trip. After your tour, get stoked up for the trip home at the Haak'u Museum's Y'akk'a Café. Sky City Cultural Center & Haak’u Museum Fullscreen Tribal elders reside in the Sky City on the mesa. Sky City Cultural Center & Haak’u Museum Fullscreen Native Americans have grown chilis in the American Southwest for at least a thousand years and they come in a mind-boggling number of varieties. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen New Mexico is the largest chili producer in the U.S., so it's no wonder they grace menus in just about every eatery in the state, sometimes with a warning. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen When ordering food in Albuquerque, if you're asked, "What color?" the question is do you want red or green chilis? If you want both, the answer is "Christmas." Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen In fall, follow your nose to find folks roasting chilis by the roadside or at farmers markets, creating an earthy, smoky smell —"New Mexico aromatherapy." Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen When peppers are left on the plant a little longer to ripen, they turn a vibrant red. They're often strung together to dry in ristras and found hanging all over New Mexico as a sign of welcome. Chili ristras also make great souvenirs. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The first Spanish explorers arrived in the area around 1540, and in 1706 a group of colonists were granted permission by King Philip of Spain to establish a new city here. San Felipe de Neri Church stands on Albuquerque’s Old Town plaza, surrounded by shops and restaurants. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen On a much less holy note, it's impossible to talk about Albuquerque without mentioning 'Breaking Bad,' the blockbuster television series filmed in ABQ. At The Candy Lady, just off the Old Town plaza, cases of beautiful handmade candy beckon along with blue rock candy created for the 'Breaking Bad' prop department to resemble what Walter White "cooked" in the series. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Among its many itineraries, ABQ Trolley Tours offers a 'Breaking Bad' tour of sights where the series was filmed, including a local fast-food chain, Twisters, which temporarily became Los Pollos Hermanos, a cover for drug kingpin Gus Fring. ABQ Trolley also guides tours of locations tied to the spinoff, 'Better Call Saul.' ABQ Trolley Fullscreen After 1926, Albuquerque grew up along the iconic Route 66, the road from Chicago to Los Angeles that John Steinbeck called America's Main Street. By 1970, Route 66 was entirely bypassed by four-lane highways, but it's now Albuquerque's Central Avenue. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Classic neon signs still line Central Avenue. The Monterey Non-Smokers Motel provides a fun and economical place to stay and experience Route 66 in its heyday. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen A few blocks from Old Town, a true only-in-Albuquerque experience, the Duran Central Pharmacy, is one of the few places where you can order a great meal — or a flu shot. Duran Central Pharmacy Fullscreen Duran Central Pharmacy's cafe is a holdover from the days of drug store soda fountains. It now serves New Mexican food and its handmade tortillas are a favorite among both locals and visitors. Duran Central Pharmacy Fullscreen Find lighter fare with gourmet salads served up at Vinaigrette, right across Central Avenue from Duran Central Pharmacy. Jen Judge Fullscreen Erin Wade, who owns Vinaigrette restaurants in both Santa Fe and Albuquerque, N.M., says, "ABQ has a younger crowd and is a really great place to live, so you are seeing a proliferation of creative concepts lately -- lots of boutique coffee shops and farm-to-table restaurants. I think there is a renaissance happening in both cities." Jen Judge Fullscreen Golden Crown Panaderia is a bakery, cafe and neighborhood hangout. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Cool off with an ice coffee and a fruit empanada at Golden Crown Panaderia. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Visitors to Golden Crown receive a free biscochito with their order. Biscochitos are melt-in-your-mouth, anise-laced shortbread cookies and are the official New Mexico State Cookie. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen On your cruise along Route 66, stop for a quick self-guided tour of the flamboyant KiMo Theater, Albuquerque's most distinctive building. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Don't try this at home… The KiMo's interior is decorated in the Pueblo Deco style, featuring cow skull sconces with glowing red eyes, Native American death canoe chandeliers and murals depicting the Seven Cities of Gold that Coronodo sought on his explorations of New Mexico. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The Frontier Restaurant serves straight-up New Mexican food with a side of quirky. Patrick Coulie Fullscreen Open from early morning until late night, it's no wonder the Frontier is a hangout for students from the University of New Mexico campus across the street. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The Frontier's five none too understated dining rooms display an extensive collection of southwestern and cowboy art. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen "The Duke," John Wayne, and "The King," Elvis Presley gaze down at diners. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The Frontier's gigantic sweet rolls could feed about four normal people — or two hungry college students. Frontier Restaurant Fullscreen The Frontier's New Mexican combo comes complete with chilis. Frontier Restaurant Fullscreen A variety of farmers' markets sprout up around Albuquerque every week from early spring until the end of October and feature everything from veggies and baked goods to art and entertainment. Downtown Growers Market Fullscreen Though the New Mexico climate is arid, farmers here grow their crops near the Rio Grande River using a system of irrigation canals called acequias. Downtown Growers Market Fullscreen The slogan at the Downtown Growers Market: "Get your picks on Route 66," says the market's manager, Robert Hoberg. "Other places base their cuisine on whatever is trendy and flown-in but in Albuquerque, our food tradition is rooted in what grows here, things like chili, squash and corn." Downtown Growers Market Fullscreen Also on Central Avenue, the Nob Hill neighborhood has become one of the city's trendiest and most distinctive areas. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen An array of one-of-a-kind shops, restaurants and local brewers congregate in Nob Hill. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The Chocolate Dude Coffee and Candy Shop offers a bit of yummy self-indulgence. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Kurt Oelsner, the Chocolate Dude himself, dips strawberries in chocolate while chatting with guests. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Among the many Chocolate Dude confections, Pinon Lobos combine chocolate, pine nuts and caramel, an Albuquerque version of the "turtle." Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Open for breakfast, lunch and dinner, Kelly's Brew Pub is a great spot for outdoor dining. It was originally the Jones Motor Company, a Ford dealership built in 1939. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Bosque Brewing Company offers food and locally-made craft beers at its Nob Hill "public house." Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen As the t-shirt says, Scotch Ale is a Bosque Brewing specialty. Bosque is the Spanish word for a group of trees by a river such as the Rio Grande in Albuquerque. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Carlos Contreras, Tractor Brewing's "good time liaison," says the city's brew pubs and tap rooms are great places to bump into people of all walks of life and movers and shakers of all kinds. Anthony Evans Fullscreen Tractor Brewing taprooms serve beer along with a rotating schedule of music and art. In fact, many staffers are also artists, poets, musicians and comedians. Anthony Evans Fullscreen A few years ago, in a classic example of food bringing a community together, the operators of the Supper Truck food truck started Tasty Tuesdays at Hyder Park in the Nob Hill neighborhood. It's grown exponentially since then. Amy Black Fullscreen Fried Chicken Banh Mi is a Supper Truck specialty. Sage Harrington Fullscreen Pop Fizz food truck serves gourmet fruit and cream popsicles, not to mention ice cream tacos. Tasty Tuesday runs from 4 p.m. until dark from spring to the end of October. Mark Ryan Fullscreen Guilt free dining? Some Tasty Tuesday visitors participate in the free yoga classes before they hit the food trucks. Amy Black Fullscreen On the northwest edge of Albuquerque, you'll find the understated luxury of Los Poblanos Inn and organic farm, not far from the Rio Grande river. In the '30s and '40s it was a model experimental farm. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Though he assists with all aspects of Los Poblanos' farm, Jason Bean is officially its head lavender farmer. Lavender, a plant that uses little water, is perfect for New Mexico growing conditions. The farm also grows much of the food for the Inn's acclaimed restaurant, La Merienda. Volunteers who want to get their hands dirty and try working on an organic farm are welcome. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Breakfast is included in your stay at Los Poblanos Inn. Sergio Salvador Photography Fullscreen Lemon blueberry bread is served with breakfast at Los Poblanos Inn. Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen Los Poblanos executive chef and Albuquerque native, Jonathan Perno, trained in France and several U.S. cities before returning to ABQ. He and his staff create contemporary Rio Grande Cuisine which focuses on "whatever comes from the Rio Grande valley." Sergio Salvador Photography Fullscreen Los Poblanos Inn guests get first dibs on dinner reservations at La Merienda where they may find dishes such as sausage pappardelle pasta for which both the sausage and pasta are housemade. Los Poblanos Fullscreen Inspired? October to March, Los Poblanos offers cooking classes on the first Sunday of the month. Sergio Salvador Photography Fullscreen If you're lucky, your meal may end with Creamsicle Panna Cotta, made with Los Poblanos figs, elderberry sauce and lavender shortbread. "When food is this fresh and harvested at the right time all I and my team have to do is treat it with respect and love and the food will speak for all of us," says Perno, Terri Peterson Smith Fullscreen The main Los Poblanos Inn building, formerly the ranch house, and La Quinta (pictured here) were designed by famed architect John Gaw Meem, "the father of Santa Fe Style." La Quinta houses an important collection of New Mexican art, gathered over many years. Los Poblanos Fullscreen The Farm Shop sells everything from locally made lavender products to t-shirts and kitchen tools. Mike & Amanda 8 CONNECT 26 TWEET 3 LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Santa Fe, N.M. gets all the attention. It takes a bit more effort to get to know Albuquerque, her more sprawling big sister to the south. Yet in ABQ, you'll find a laid-back city with a character all her own. Albuquerque doesn't need a slogan like Santa Fe's "City Different." It just is. They have a rattlesnake museum — enough said.
Nowhere is Albuquerque's heritage, ethnic diversity and personality more apparent than in its food culture. Like a drive through history, a tour of Albuquerque's drinking and dining spots includes Native American cuisine, places to get your food and drink "kicks on Route 66" (now Albuquerque's main street, Central Avenue), and the city's more contemporary and sophisticated "Rio Grande Cuisine." Here, many cultures — Native American, Spanish, Mexican and Anglo influences — meld in a complex stew, all seasoned with a whopping helping of chilis.
Browse the gallery above for where to eat and explore around Albuquerque, N.M.
